source_citation: Republican Party Platforms, Republican Party Platform of 1924 Online by Gerhard Peters and John T. Woolley, The American Presidency Project
title_or_description_from_source: Allowing congress to regulate child labor
text_of_amendment: We commend congress for having recognized this possibility in its prompt adoption of the recommendation of President Coolidge for a constitutional amendment authorizing congress to legislate on the subject of child labor, and we urge the prompt consideration of that amendment by the legislatures of the various states.
notes: This case was also the subject of Coleman v, Miller (1939), in which the Supreme Court held that the timeline of proposed amendments is a political question that only legislatures have the power to decide.

source_citation: "Ask Congress for Child Labor Law," The Seattle Star, Volume 25, Issue 32, 3 April 1923, 5.
title_or_description_from_source: Child Labor
text_of_amendment: Regulate child labor thruout the country

source_citation: "Curb on Supreme Court Urged; Restriction of Child Labor," Muncie Post-Democrat, Volume 3, Issue 14, 27 April 1923, 3.
title_or_description_from_source: Child and Women's Labor
text_of_amendment: women's minimum wage and child labor

source_citation: "Miner Brands Short as 'Cur' in Labor Movement," The Seattle Star, Volume 25, Issue 117, 11 July 1923, 1;9.
title_or_description_from_source: Child and Women's Labor
text_of_amendment: The congress shall have concurrent power with the several states to regulate and prohibit the employment at labor of children under 16 years of age, the several states retaining their existing power with respect to such regulation and prohibition, subject to the limitation that no employment of any such child made unlawful by law of congress shall be permitted in any state.

source_citation: "Prosperity Has Serious Fault," The Seattle Star, Volume 25, Issue 155, 24 August 1923, 10.
title_or_description_from_source: Child Labor
text_of_amendment: Give congress the right to legislate regarding the employment of all persons under 15 years of age.
notes: Chief od the Children's Bureau of the Department of Labor

source_citation: "Dr. Ryan Advocates Child Labor Amendment," Catholic News Service, Volume 4, Issue 39, 31 December 1923, 14.
title_or_description_from_source: Child Labor
text_of_amendment: The power to enact laws for the protection of women and children in industry
notes: Director of the Department of Social Action of the National Catholic Welfare Conference (Proposal given before the American Association for Labor Legislation)

source_citation: "Jewish Women to vote on Prize Peace Plan," The Indiana Jewish Chronicle, Volume 7, Issue 37, 4 January 1924, 1.
title_or_description_from_source: Child Labor
text_of_amendment: Permit congress to legislate on the child labor question.
notes: The Committee included representatives from 19 organizations. The leaders included Samuel Gompers, president of the American Federation of Labor; Miss Grace Abbott, chief of the Federal Children's Bureau; Mrs. Maude Wood Park, president of the National League of Women Voters, and Father C. O. Ryan, of the Catholic Council, and Mrs. Alexander Wolf of Washington, D.C., second vice-president of the National Council of Jewish Women.

source_citation: "McAdoo to Run," The American Standard, Volume 1, Issue 4, 1 March 1924, 4.
title_or_description_from_source: Child Labor
notes: In his platform when running for the 1924 Democratic presidential nomination

source_citation: Jane Perry Clark, "Some Recent Proposals for Constitutional Amendment," Wisconsin Law Review 12, no. 3 (April 1937): 313-336.
title_or_description_from_source: Permit states to specify maximum working hours, minimum wage, and working conditions for women and children
text_of_amendment: I shall favor a constitutional amendment permitting States to adopt such legislation as may be necessary adequately to protect women and children in the matter of maximum hours, minimum wages, and working conditions. This obligation we cannot escape.

source_citation: Johnson, Donald Bruce and Kirk H. Porter, National Party Platforms Rev. ed. v. 1. Urbana: University of Illinois Press, 1978, 292.
title_or_description_from_source: Child Labor
text_of_amendment: Enacting of an adequate federal anti-child labor amendment

source_citation: Johnson, Donald Bruce and Kirk H. Porter, National Party Platforms Rev. ed. v. 1. Urbana: University of Illinois Press, 1978, 353.
title_or_description_from_source: Social Services
text_of_amendment: The passage of the Socialist Party's proposed Worker's rights amendment to the Constitution empowering Congress to establish national systems of unemployment, health and accident insurance and old age pensions, to abolish child labor, establish and take over enterprises in manufacture, commerce, transportation, banking, public utilities, and other business and industries to be owned and operated by the Government, and generally, for the social and economic welfare of the workers of the United States.
